original: The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the centre-left think tank in Sheffield. The report has also detailed a number of "tests" or benchmarks for the government's northern powerhouse scheme. Research by the IPPR showed only 47% of children born in the poorest families in the north of England achieved a good level of early years development compared with 59% in London. Its survey also found five northern city-regions combined had almost as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million) - but the IPPR forecasts demand for skilled workers in the North is set to increase. The IPPR has proposed 11 benchmarks for Chancellor George Osborne's flagship policy to boost regional
sampled:
The Institute of Public Policy Research (IPPR) said London's poorest children outperformed those in the north. The report is being launched by the centre-left think-tank at a London reception today (26 May).

According to the report, in 2011-12 the average gap in reading and writing between working-class and most middle-class children in Westminster increased to 9.6.

The report says children living in the poorest neighbourhoods of the city performed better than their counterparts in other areas.

There were only 43 pupils admitted to special homes in Westminster last year and their reading achievement was above average for London, while the average reading achievement of the city's poorest children in Westminster was 3.7 percentage points higher than the average in Oxford and 4.9 points higher than those in the richest areas of London's boroughs.

Pupils were also less likely to be in a school where there was segregation of pupils on racial, ethnic or other grounds.

AP said later: "The @AP twitter account has been hacked. The tweet about an attack at the White House is false." The account was back online on Wednesday. But the number of job vacancies dropped by 18,000 to 745,000, the ONS added, marking the first fall for almost a year. The Office for National Statistics said industrial output grew 5.8% in 2013, driven by a 5.1% rise in the volume of goods produced. GDP per person grew 5.1%, largely at the expense of prices.

The latest data also showed the manufacturing trade deficit narrowed from £13.05bn earlier to just £5.34bn for the 12 months.

original: OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. But Mr Soskice said the story samples he used were not representative of the whole range of stories submitted during the last year, and they were a poor measure of how children are developing writing skills. He also said the samples do not reveal the way children process stories online, or the role stories play in their self-concepts and how they understand the world.

These numbers are likely to be even higher and indicate potential audience numbers of the order of 40 – 60 million people. Three unnamed police forces in England and Wales are taking part in a pilot scheme following the study. Coercive or controlling behaviour became a criminal offence last year. The research found that although most domestic abuse incidents were handled in a "professional" way, some officers still displayed "negative and uninformed" attitudes. In particular, police tended to neglect cases where suspects did not use violence but tried to control their victim in other ways such as by making threats. The report said: "A tendency for the police to focus on physical violence and what has occurred at the current incident can result in them missing abuse which is characterised not by physical violence and injury but by continuous coercion and control in other forms." Murray, the current world number four doubles player, has won both the US and Australian Open titles with his Brazilian tennis partner Bruno Soares. The 30-year-old has just beaten John Isner in the fourth round of the Miami final, a feat which is unprecedented in a professional tennis match so far this year, which has featured just four doubles matches.

Murray has also emerged as a formidable singles player. Since making the switch to the men's game in 2013, Murray has gone on to beat all four players in the 2015 United States Open and is currently ranked the highest ranking player in the world, according to the rankings for 2016.

The Open Championships, in Washington DC, comes up in August. There are three more rounds of tennis, and the top 16 in the rankings get to play in the 2015 Wimbledon tournament, which starts on 29 July.

original: PNG Prime Minister Peter O'Neill said in a statement he had met Australia's immigration minister, Peter Dutton, in Port Moresby on Wednesday. "Both PNG and Australia are in agreement that [Manus Island] centre is to be closed," the statement said. PNG's Supreme Court found in April that detaining asylum seekers and refugees at the centre was unconstitutional. Mr O'Neill said the Manus Regional Processing Centre, which currently houses 854 men, would not close immediately. What next for Manus Island asylum seekers? "A series of options are being advanced and implemented," Mr O'Neill said. "It is important that this process is not rushed but carried out in a careful manner. "This must take into account the interests of the people of Papua New Guinea and the wellbeing of asylum seekers and refugees." Australia sends asylum seekers who arrive in the country by boat to offshore detention centres in Manus Island and the Pacific nation

original: BBC One will show a special programme, Strictly Len Goodman, on Friday. The National Grid said the show would drive the biggest festive "TV pickup" - a sudden surge in electricity demand. The spike is largely down to viewers turning on lights and boiling their kettles straight after the programme. There is also a surge in the number of people going to the bathroom, which leads to a spike in the use of water companies' pumps, which draw electricity. The Great British Bake Off, the Strictly Christmas special and Call the Midwife are also expected to create high demand over the Christmas period. But TV surges create less demand now than they did 20 years ago because more people use catch-up services to watch TV

Now available in e-book format, the story has been turned into a comic by comic book artist David Petersen, who has been nominated for a BONOR award for best new artist. But one of the book's greatest qualities is just how easy it is to consume. There's no need for patience, like with some high-end art books, to really make an impression. In this novel, each page can be read in hours, even on an iPad.

The 55-year-old is the first military prisoner from Afghanistan to be tried in a US federal court. Some of the charges carry a mandatory life sentence. Hamidullin, who did not testify during the trial, is expected to be sentenced on 6 November. Lawyers say it is unusual for someone captured on the battlefield in Afghanistan to be transferred to the United States for trial in a federal court. completed: He started the project after growing frustrated about the number of options and amount of recorded information on call centre menus . The RMT said a proposal would see staff lose all health and pensions benefits, while management control over the company's hiring and firing policies would be transferred to a so-called'safety team' which will be made up of train drivers. Other unions such as ASLEF, the Rail, Maritime and Transport (RMT) union, did not join the walkouts.

In April, the RMT announced a similar walkout after the London Underground passed the controversial Tube driver-only-operated (DOO) contract, prompting Transport for London (TfL) to halt the changes, and calling in an emergency board meeting with Tube staff.

The Tube strike comes less than a month after Southern Railway announced that its drivers could be forced to work on the platform when work requires it. This followed

original: Researchers were able to make drops grow six times faster than normal by copying the insects' shell geometry. Combined with other plant techniques, the team created drops that grew larger as temperatures increased. The authors say the development could significantly improve water harvesting and electricity generation. A little drop of water may seem insignificant but the physical processes involved in both the formation and movement of the liquid are essential to operation of thermal power plants, desalination and air conditioning systems. Condensation is also critical to the more fundamental function of gathering water for human use in dry climates, a growing, global issue. Researchers have made previous attempts to mimic the remarkable abilities of the Namib beetle, which uses its bumpy shell to draw all the water it needs from periodic, foggy winds in the desert. The assumption until now has been that the surface chemistry of the beetle's back has been the key - but this new study says that it's actually the physical arrangement

He said: "The attack will have affected lots of people in some way or another but most will find they recover naturally and don't require any professional support. Before he died, he published an autobiographical account based on his experiences of the First World War and his subsequent career as an officer in the Army of the Thames. He died suddenly in 1913, aged only 50, and was buried in the Blues' family plot at the old London Athletic Grounds stadium.

His father, Henry, and grandfather, Thomas, who had served in the Navy, were each buried at the same plot after their deaths. The trial is the second by the IPCC in Northern, and the first in England and Wales, and is the culmination of two investigations into deaths of unarmed, black people by police.

Fighter planes, mainly Hurricanes, flew from the site during the Battle of Britain in 1940. The RAF left the base, just off the M11 near Epping, in 1964 and it is currently used by businesses and small aircraft. North Weald in Essex was established in 1916 as an RAF base for fighter planes to combat airship raids over London. Fighter planes, mainly Hurricanes, were based there from 1916 to 1918. Two years later, British planes also dropped supplies to the French troops fighting the Germans in Africa. In 1917 British servicemen set up the first permanent police station, the Chichester Police Post. The base included a fire station, four air-raid shelters and a telephone exchange with a telephone operator who was able to switch to German on the first ring (this was one of a number of secret telegraph lines run under the table in the base). As part of the effort to counter German submarine activity off the coast of Britain, RAF Typhoons were also based at Weald in 1917. Weald also saw military aircraft being used for practice runs by the Royal Flying Corps.

Those with higher levels of emotional investment in social media, and who use it at night, were more likely to feel depressed and anxious, they say.

"People who use social media at night are more likely to be depressed, more likely to seek the help of their medical profession, more likely to binge drink — and more likely to use illegal drugs," the researchers wrote in their findings.

The study is the first to show increased negative emotions in night users compared with those who wake up.

The findings indicate that not all night users experience increased negative emotions.

"This is very important because night activity is only one of many factors that contribute to negative emotions. The books were originally used by the Benedictine monks of Durham until the dissolution of monasteries by Henry VIII from 1536-41. Many collections across the country were broken up, but Durham's remained intact and includes "masterpieces of calligraphy... spanning a millennium of European culture", the university said. Lisa Di Tommaso, head of collections at Durham Cathedral, said: "It is one of the most complete in situ collections in the British Isles with the oldest pieces dating back to the 6th Century. "In their original manuscripts there are not even a few words of Latin."

Professor Paul S. Cziborowski, director of the university's new Centre of Research Excellence in Medieval and Early Modern England, said: "There are over 40,000 copies of the documents at Durham University, but these scans will allow us to see a tremendous amount of detail; they will reveal many more items of interest within the collections."

The scanned documents from the library are being catalogued in the Oxford Bibliomania Online (OBO) catalogue, so that researchers and enthusiasts alike can use these to learn more about medieval life and literature. The catalogue is available at http://www.bibliomaniaonline.org

original: The case concerns a Virginia public school district trying to prevent a female-born 17-year-old transgender student from using the boys' bathroom. The justices are expected to rule on the case before the end of June. The high court is one justice short after the death of Antonin Scalia, which could lead to a 4-4 decision. Schools districts nationwide remain conflicted on whether to require transgender students to use bathrooms corresponding with the sex listed on their birth certificates. The case concerns a Virginia public school district trying to prevent a female-born 17-year-old transgender student from using the boys' bathroom. The court will determine whether a student has the right to use a restroom consistent with their gender identity.

Texas and Oklahoma both have laws on the books that bar transgender people from using public restrooms that don't correspond to their birth gender. Transgender people are barred from using public restrooms using "alternative facilities" that do not match their gender at birth. But courts have been split on whether requiring transgender people to use bathrooms that do not exactly correspond to their anatomy is a violation of the constitutional rights of people to privacy and bodily privacy.

The "loneliness maps" could be used to target limited resources at the people and places that need them most. The Hidden Citizens report, published by the Invisible Institute and the Open Technology Institute, looked at anonymized government data on more than 300 million users from the US Department of Veterans Affairs and found that those veterans suffering most from the biggest social problems are often often those most alone. The project's report also highlights the fact that people who appear most isolated aren't necessarily the most vulnerable to loneliness: there were no "loneliness maps" for people who had recently lost someone close to them.

"We know that there are a lot of reasons people don't feel they're getting the support they need. A lot of those reasons are connected to issues of isolation or loneliness," said David Amodio, who co-authored the Hidden Citizens report with Jason Hall, a Harvard economist. "That's a really strong pattern we see from all the research."

Denis Donaldson was murdered in County Donegal in April 2006, months after being exposed as an agent who worked for the police and MI5 for the previous seven years.

The murder of Donaldson comes amid renewed concern over the level of undercover police officers operating in Northern Ireland.

A total of 31 police officers were jailed for acts of misconduct, including four undercover officers whose covert work during the Good Friday talks led to widespread public concern during the unrest leading to the Good Friday Agreement.

The revelations come after the DUP's justice spokesman, Mark Durkan, asked the Attorney General to investigate allegations some gardaí may have been involved in any illegal activity.

Garda sources have said two alleged officers and a sergeant under the direction of Sgt Maurice McCabe in 2009 took part in an MI5 undercover operation.

The allegations have not been proven and, if substantiated, they could bring criminal convictions.
